segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya bārāṇasiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Benares for alms.

segments.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā goyogapilakkhasmiṃ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ rittassādaṃ bāhirassādaṃ muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ pākatindriyaṃ.
segments.en: While the Buddha was walking for alms near the cow-hitching place at the wavy leaf fig, he saw a disgruntled monk who was looking for pleasure in external things, unmindful, without situational awareness or immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.

segments.pli: Taṃ vata, bhikkhu, kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
segments.en: If you’re bitter, corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.”

segments.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovadito saṃvegamāpādi.
segments.en: Hearing this advice of the Buddha, that monk was struck with a sense of urgency.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, the Buddha told the mendicants what had happened. …

segments.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya bārāṇasiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.
Addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, goyogapilakkhasmiṃ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ rittassādaṃ bāhirassādaṃ muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ pākatindriyaṃ.
Taṃ vata bhikkhu kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti.
Atha kho, bhikkhave, so bhikkhu mayā iminā ovādena ovadito saṃvegamāpādī”ti.
Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
What is the ‘stench of rotting flesh’?
ill will is the stench of rotting flesh;
and bad, unskillful thoughts are the flies.

segments.pli: Taṃ vata, bhikkhu, kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatīti.
segments.en: If you’re bitter, corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.
When your eyes and ears are unguarded,
and you’re not restrained in your sense faculties,
corrupted by the stench of rotting flesh,
if they don’t find serenity in themselves,
since they’ve got rid of the flies.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares,…

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha helps a monk in distress by teaching of “bitterness”, “rotting flesh”, and “flies”.
